title: Tuesday, 13th September, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE

Hey, hello, hi, welcome.

BE

And today, instead of a portrait, I've got an email.

BE

An email to me. This email.

11:02 am
BE

BE

Uber does a lot of these emails.

BE

In the past year it's lobbied me (a not particularly important customer, with weekly spend in the low double figures and a 4.7 approval rating) many many times about TFL policies

11:04 am
BE

All with "SIGN THE PETITION" and "EMAIL THE MAYOR" links included

BE

When you hit the button and it even writes a wee letter for you. All you have to do is click send.

BE

11:05 am
BE

I didn't write any of that! Yet I seem to have signed it!

BE

Okay, so I don't know how to feel about this.

BE

Partly because I like cheap taxis. Really like them.

11:06 am
BE

I like that Fidelity, Tata Capital and the Saudi Arabia Public Investment Fund are subsidising my ability to get home from the pub.

BE

But ...... well ....these kind of lobby tactics via direct marketing are a bit like rabble rousing, aren't they?

BE

We also have the cognitive dissonance of a $70bn company trying to sound like the underdog.

11:06 am
BE

From today's email ....

BE

Many drivers who use Uber are immigrants. They work hard to look after themselves and their families. Driving has given them an opportunity to integrate into their local community. The Mayor should be supporting these drivers, not penalising them.

BE

"Use" .......

11:07 am
BE

(@Flaneur: we're worse than cheap, we're free.)

undefined
BE

Okay, so live we have the FTSE doing very very little.

11:09 am
BE

6,706, up about a 6 point gain.

BE

Bounced off 6680 earlier, for no particular reason.

BE

Any sense of direction continues to be tied entirely on the vaguest of guidance from Fed folk

11:11 am
BE

Today's relative calm can be attributed to comments from Brainard that were banal more than dovish.

BE

Rates shouldn't go up too quickly .... well, yes. Too quickly would be too quickly. But that's all we have to go on at the moment, resulting in this markets atrophy .....

BE

..... Let me seee if I can pad this put with a bit of strategy waffle.

11:16 am
BE

SocGen has its investment totality bumf out this morning. That'll do.

BE

BE

Overall stance: gearing to three key changing drivers
In developed countries, fiscal impetus is gaining momentum while monetary policies have
reached a point where the central banks cannot do much more other than turn to helicopter
money. We increase our exposure to DM equities (US, +5 points) somewhat at the expense of
bonds (euro area peripherals, -2 points) on the view that DM growth and inflation might
surprise on the upside.
In emerging markets the growth outlook is clearly getting brighter while key risks are
diminishing. In particular, following the exit of President Rousseff, the political crisis in Brazil is
cooling, capital outflows and the prospects of a hard landing in China are receding, and
Russia is moving out of recession. Lower inflation will be a key feature in the coming quarters,
allowing central banks to continue if not accelerate monetary policy loosening which would
provide a strong boost to EM assets. We prefer bonds (overweight, 8 points, unchanged) to
equities (5 points, unchanged) in EM.
Commodity prices should be boosted by a higher growth environment and, with G10 inflation
set to pick up, commodities as an asset class continue to offer an attractive risk-reward
balance (overweight, 8 points, -3). We prefer to get exposure to undervalued commodity
currencies via a mix of Canadian (CAD), Norwegian (NOK), Russian (RUB) and Brazilian (BRL)
currencies (allocated 10 points), while we maintain a strong negative bias on sterling.
In this context, we slightly increase our overall equity exposure (+5 points to 50) and further
reduce exposure to government bonds in G10 (-2). We reaffirm our clear, positive view on
emerging assets that we adopted in the last quarter of last year.

11:17 am
BE

US assets ahead of the elections: prefer equities to bonds
The two key contestants in the upcoming US Presidential election on 8 November both lack
good quality projects and have some of the worst ratings historically. What stands out
however is that both candidates want to boost growth and inflation through increased fiscal
spending, especially infrastructure investment. In this context, we increase our US equity
exposure (+ 5 points to 19).
The US Treasury market offers some protection thanks to a high carry versus other G10 bond
markets, and the Federal Reserve keeps saying it will increase rates somewhat (surprises
would therefore come more from euro area tapering next year). We’re however becoming shy
at the very long end of the curve of the sovereign bond market. What may be good for
corporate assets (growth and inflation are good for corporate profits) may also be bad for
bonds. Our quantitative tools highlight a preference for cash over bonds in a risk-averse
scenario, clearly highlighting that bonds no longer offer defensive qualities.

BE

Strong commodity exposure to protect from rising G10 inflation
This year the oil market absorbed excess capacity and reached a new equilibrium thanks to
improved demand and falling supply (both US shale oil and Canadian sands). In the second
half of 2017 we expect stock draws to result in a market deficit (or around 1 mb/d). Oil itself is
highly attractive with $50, $60, $70 as house targets for end 2016, 2017 and 2018.
Beyond oil itself, we recommend three associated investment ideas: 1) the global oil equity
sector, where dividend distribution should be relatively safe, 2) undervalued commodity
currencies with a higher beta than the commodity markets themselves in G10 (CAD, NOK) and
EM (RUB, BRL), 3) inflation-protected bonds (5 points, max weighting, unchanged).
We particularly like UK linkers (+2) to benefit from the devaluation of sterling associated with
the Brexit referendum. Thanks to their very high average duration, pension funds use linkers to
reduce their asset liability mismatch. We also recommend US and euro area linkers.

BE

Strong exposure to EM assets, notably currencies and bonds
Growth is clearly bottoming out in emerging market countries and the growth gap with
developed economies should increase in the coming years. With EM inflation regimes
expected to shift lower, some EM central banks should be able to ease monetary policies.
With real yields of 2 to 4%, EM government bonds are highly attractive. Inflows have started
into both bonds and equities. We particularly like Latin American assets, with Brazil the clear
outsider. EM Europe also looks attractive, being a beneficiary of euro area acceleration and
reduced risks from Russia, still our favourite in the region.
China’s hard-landing risk is receding while the authorities provide fiscal support when
necessary and outflows are receding thank to capital controls. SOE restructuring however
could trigger instability which is why China is not a preferred area of investment in our MAP.
One way to protect against a surprise election of Donald Trump is a RUB/MXN trade. Only 3%
of Russian exports are to the US (versus 80% of Mexico exports).

11:18 am
BE

Japan and euro area - monetary policy could disappoint
The euro area economy is resilient with Brexit having had little if any impact on growth
prospects. Some worries remain, however, ranging from the Italian constitutional referendum
to bank recapitalisation, while sovereign bond spreads have tightened significantly after
Brexit. As a consequence we slightly reduce our exposure to euro area peripheral bonds.
Japan’s next policy step will be large fiscal stimulus. Although market expectations for further
monetary policy easing are high, the quantity of asset buying is already elevated at 14% of
GDP. We believe there is scope for disappointment: the risk scenarios imply a tailwind for the
yen and a headwind for local equities.
Finally, don’t be fooled by the resilience of the UK economy during the summer period.
Uncertainties about the real economic consequences of Brexit remain. The Bank of England
could continue to use sterling as a weapon and allow the currency to slide further. We remain
sellers of the UK currency, maintain a strong weighting in UK equities, and add to holdings of
UK inflation protected bonds, the latter hedged via a basket of commodity-linked currencies.

BE

I guess the interesting lines to pick out from all that is that they're going for another leg down for sterling

BE

Once the Brexit impact is visible (their argument, not mine)

11:20 am
BE

Buy commodities and EM

BE

And beware the return of inflation in the G10 ex Japan.

undefined
11:21 am
BE

And to corporate, I guess.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 277.60, down 44.4 (-13.79%), High: 312.40, Low: 273.00, Volume: 3.09m
BE

!

11:22 am
BE

Warning of “sustained and continuing margin pressure” seems to have done the damage.

BE

Figures are slightly light.

BE

And there's definitely a trend towards doing volume rather than margin.

11:23 am
BE

Average order per week increased by 18.9%

BE

But total average basket price fell 4.5%

BE

Some of the blame there goes on Ocado's satellite operations .....

11:24 am
BE

"Fetch", "Sizzle" and "Fabled" .....

BE

..... (nope, me neither).

BE

Mostly, though, it's just competition. Here's Morgan Stanley.

11:25 am
BE

Bottom line: Ocado posted a resilient sales update, especially when considering
the ongoing deflationary pressures and tough industry backdrop. Having spoken
to the company, the tone remains confident over the medium term, but
somewhat cautious into the H2 due to the deflationary pressures flagged
already in Ocado's previous releases. Overall, we believe this trading update is
more or less consistent with a full-year EBITDA in the mid-80s, which would
compare to the current median consensus of ~£90m (although those analysts
having more recently republished tend to be lower than this), so despite the
resilient top line update we suspect full-year EBITDA could come down
somewhat on the back of today's release.

BE

Retail sales growth stood at +13.6%, broadly in line with consensus expectations
and with what Ocado achieved in H1 (+13.9%). Total basket size contraction
continued to impact Ocado's top line, with order size declining by 4.5% YoY
(accelerating sequentially but broadly stable on a 2-year basis). Part of this
deflation relates to the deflationary impact of the more recent (and still ramping
up) specialist websites, but on the core Ocado.com website, the average basket
order size nevertheless declined by -3.4% YoY in Q3 (vs. -2.5% in Q2) – see below
table. Encouragingly, order growth continued to accelerate, standing at +18.9%
over the quarter, which Ocado highlights as its best volume performance in more
than five years. There was no mention of CFC3 in the release, but Ocado only
guided to an opening at some point in its H2 (and the higher volumes of the
Autumn season are only picking up now)

BE

Cash: Ocado's cash position stood at £48m as of the end of Q3 (vs. £53m as of
the end of Q2). We understand this is in line with the company's budget.

11:27 am
BE

Cash burn! Sixteen years into operation and still burning cash!

BE

Still can't turn a profit on the business of delivering beans to one geographically compressed market!

BE

But don't worry, it's a logistics outsourcer now. Just as soon as it finds someone to outsource to.

11:28 am
BE

Outlook: In the release, Ocado reiterates its cautious outlook (talking about a
"very competitive market", or slightly stronger than the "competitive market" they
spoke about at their interims), flagging once again the deflationary pressures in
the market, which should in turn weigh on their margins. In terms of top line,
Ocado continues to expect to grow ahead of the online grocery market, and
substantially ahead of the market overall

BE

Just piecing through the bits of the conference call ....

BE

CFO says he "wouldn’t be surprised” if FY estimates fall

11:31 am
BE

One doesn't want to throw around the word "warning" too liberally, but if you're a CFO and you're not comfortable with market expectations, isn't there a process in place for reducing them?

BE

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily this thing, from an overheating London.

BE

We continue to believe that Ocado is a grossly over-valued equity based upon any sensible valuation analysis set against its largely disappointing delivery to date and far from stellar financial prospects. Indeed, one could reasonably argue still that the stratospheric multiples that the stocks enjoys implies structural upgrades and/or a premium take-over; none of which appears to be on the horizon.

11:32 am
BE

Whilst this is so and, to be fair to us, it has been a consistent theme of our narrative on Ocado, we feel that there has been some strategic progress in recent times that paves the way for improved sentiment, possibly involving some more pleasing market announcements. That progress, to our minds revolves around:

· The signing of the agreement with Morrisons+ (MRW, House Stock at 195p), which paves the way to progress with Customer Fulfilment Centre (CFC) 4 at Erith in Kent and so creates a basis for growth in tandem with the superstore group beyond CFC2 at Dordon (Warwickshire) even if CEO, Tim Steiner, had to accept materially less benevolent terms on the new facility and the putting of a horse and cart through prior eCommerce restrictions for Morrisons.

· We believe that the agreement with Morrisons may pave the way for further tie-ups with store based supermarkets in the UK. We will watch with interest to see if Ocado can manage improved relations with Waitrose (John Lewis Partnership), the latter of which has evolved a stronger negotiating position to our minds with the dual operation of Coulsdon (London) alongside working with Mr. Steiner's group. Waitrose also has a new Managing Director in Rob Collins, who may bring a fresh pair of eyes to matters. Furthermore, the new arrangements with Morrisons may also permit exploratory discussions by Ocado with the Co-op and Marks & Spencer^ (MKS, Buy at 326p) in our view.

· Ocado has foolishly, to our minds, made commitments to third party international tie-ups that have not been fulfilled whatsoever ever to date. Whilst there is no further progress on the matter today (13th September), with the Morrison agreement in-tow, we see a more sound basis for such announcements to commence, noting that an announcement is one thing, tie-ups that make a meaningful difference to earning and free cash flow are quite another.

BE

Accordingly, following this update, Ocado remains a relatively fast growing but ultimately small and dependent group to us; we do not really consider the business to be a proprietary grocer since it is so dependent upon third parties. That said with the Morrison agreement now re-engineered, we believe that sentiment can improve based upon one or two points of new news flow rather than empty promises. As such, we see sentiment towards the stock being more stable and consistent, accounting for our more neutral position and so our HOLD stance on the company’s shares. With Ocado's profitability remaining de minimus and its valuation metrics continuing to be stretched, noting the considerable capitalisation of costs, we shall re-visit our financial forecasts and adjust accordingly following this update

BE

That's Clive Black, of course.

11:33 am
undefined
BE

What else, then? Kinda quiet for corporate.

BE

ESure's confirmed that it's spinning off GoCompare

11:35 am
esure Group PLC (ESUR:LSE): Last: 292.80, up 5.6 (+1.95%), High: 296.40, Low: 288.20, Volume: 385.43k
BE

Boom! Look at that release of trapped value! A whole 5p!

BE

Now, I know we go on about price comparison sites a lot here, ROTR .....

11:37 am
BE

.... but it occurred to me this morning .... Have there been any proper studies done to show that self-selection of financial products gives customers better results?

BE

The entire fintech sector seems to be locked into the idea that if you give people information to make choices, they'll be offered better options and choose between them optimally. This seems very much a theory, however.

BE

Anyway, let me spin back to esure. Here's RBC.

11:39 am
BE

Strategic review results in demerger of Gocompare
esure announced that it will pursue a demerger of Gocompare as a
result of the strategic review that it launched in June 2016. Subject to
approvals, the deal should occur in Q4 2016 and will incur costs of c£19m.
esure believes that Gocompare as a standalone entity will be able to
attract more technology focused employees who will be more interested
in joining a digital company. Prior to the demerger being completed,
Gocompare is expected to draw down on a £75m debt facility and pay
a cash dividend of £63m to esure. Following the demerger, esure will
target an SCR of 130-150%, an increase on the SCR of 126% at 1H16,
and sees no change to current dividend policy. We believe the increase in
esure's solvency ratio should help esure's standing as a standalone motor
insurance business vs peers.

BE

Investment thesis crystallising
Our positive investment thesis was borne of our belief that the market
fundamentally undervalues Gocompare as part of esure. We have written
about this extensively in several notes including 'Good value when you
Gocompare: Initiating at Outperform' and 'What happens when you
Gocompare'. We believe that today's announced demerger should help
shareholders to crystallise value in the company. If we were to value
esure's earnings excluding Gocompare at 13x, this implies that Gocompare
would trade on 14x 2017E earnings, a large discount to the P/E multiple
of Moneysupermarket (20x 2017E).

BE

Scenario analysis - range between 310p and 394p per share
We re-run our scenario analysis from our 7th June 2016 note and generate
a valuation range between 310p and 394p. Arguably, Gocompare's
only real comparable is Moneysupermarket, given the price comparison
business that they both focus on. If we value Gocompare's 2017E
earnings at a 20% discount to Moneysupermarket's multiple and value the
remainder of esure's earnings at 13x, we generate a 310p valuation (our
base case). However, if progress continues to be strong, then potentially
Gocompare could re-rate to a Moneysupermarket multiple which would
suggest a valuation of 338p. If we use the trading multiples of internetfocused peers such as Zoopla, Autotrader, and Rightmove, this leads to a
valuation of 394p per share, however, we would argue that this is more
of a blue sky scenario.

11:40 am
BE

Hm.

BE

I don't understand why price comparison engines should make so much money and also provide a valuable service. Given the natural opposition and the need to be a bit clandestine with fees etc, I don't understand how it can be considered a sustainable model.

BE

I'm in the minority though. Here's Caz.

11:42 am
BE

Esure this morning announced the conclusion of its strategic review of its
price comparison business GoCompare.com. Esure confirms that it intends
demerge the business, and will separately list it on the LSE main market in
Q4. On listing, GoCompare shares will be distributed to Esure shareholders
via an interim pro-rata dividend in specie. We have previously given a range
of estimates for the standalone value of GoCompare and the implied SoTP for
Esure group - at the current share price, based on our base estimate of £466m
for GoCompare, we estimate the remaining insurance operations at just 10.3x
our FY18e. We see the demerger as a strategically sensible action that will
crystallize the sum-of-the-parts value for shareholders. OW.
 Esure to demerge and separately list GoCompare.com in Q4: Having
completed the strategic review announced in June, Esure has today
confirmed that it plans to separately list GoCompare on the LSE main
market. The intention is to distribute GoComapre.com shares as an interim
dividend in specie, with additional information on GoCompare set to be
provided on the 11th October ahead of its listing in Q4 2016.
 New Solvency range 130-150%: The new GoCompare entity will draw on
a new £75m debt facility and pay a c£63m cash dividend to Esure. This will
cover the fees involved with the demerger and also boost Esure's standalone
solvency, which is expected to be in the middle to upper end of the new
range. Esure had not previously given a preferred range but stated that it
was comfortable at its current Solvency position of 126% as at 1H16.
Although the capital requirements of Esure's insurance business are not
expected to change, we believe the preference for a higher ratio post
separation is driven by the removal of GoCompare's cash flows.
 Dividend policy unchanged: Esure will retain its dividend policy of 50% of
underlying PAT, which is supplemented by special dividends when capital
surpluses are deemed to occur. We expect further details on GoCompare's
distribution policy to be provided with the prospectus prior to its listing.
 Revisiting our SOTP: We provide a range of valuations for the Esure group
based on separate assumptions for Esure and GoCompare. If we use 13x our
FY18E for Esure and 15x for GoCompare (20% discount to MONY.L) we
arrive at our 340p TP, although arguably these may prove conservative.
These calculations do not include the £19m in one-off costs and possible £1-
2m (we estimate) Plc costs for GoCompare.

undefined
BE

(Do we still have a CAB?)

11:44 am
BE

Elsewhere, then ......

BE

..... I note the international tax debate on the right without for the moment trying to get my head around where it's moving towards.

BE

Lisa Pollack's "Bitching About Starbucks" series remains the best thing I've read on the theme, even if it's a few years old now. If you haven't, you probably should: http://ftalphavill...g-about-starbucks/

11:46 am
BE

On the subject of tax-efficient companies though ....

Associated British Foods plc (ABF:LSE): Last: 2,726, down 89.1 (-3.17%), High: 2,777, Low: 2,682, Volume: 805.81k
BE

Jefferies re-does its numbers on Primark and comes out with a rather lower PE.

11:47 am
BE

Here it is in pictures.

BE

BE

And here are the words.

11:48 am
BE

Despite the precipitous, FY IMS triggered ABF sell-off, we remain concerned
that the Primark investment debate will now revolve around more normalised
valuation criteria. With a third successive year of Primark margin falls now
expected for 16/17, we value the division on 23x P/E, and see double-digit
downside to the stock.

BE

Reviewing the model following clear indications by ABF of accelerating Primark margin
pressures in H2 15/16, and into 16/17. These will likely be moderated by a strong build
in sugar profits. Still, at group level the net result is a 1% cut to 16/17 EPS (to 2% sub
consensus), with near -4% to 17/18 (to 7% below consensus).

BE

Major Primark downgrades... The last time we wrote at length on ABF, we noted fairly
unusual initiatives in Primark stores (Primarking Its Territory?) in mid S/S season. At that time we speculated that greater encroachment by online challengers may have pushed Primark into some uncharacteristic in-store communication to shoppers. Since then, we also picked up on major price resets at ITX's Lefties in Spain (see charts). And, seen in this context, Primark's commitment 'to leading the value sector' suggest the business will step up pricing action in A/W 16/17. A sharper value offering at a time of accelerating, fx-driven sourcing pressures (and with a slower support than expected from the openings programme) sees us downgrade our EBIT estimates by between 7% and 10% (with JEFe EBIT margin of 9.7% from 16/17 onwards).

11:49 am
BE

...partly offset by sugar upgrades. The cont'd recovery in sugar prices will be fully felt
in 16/17, and we have upgraded our European price assumption to €510/tonne. We expect this to partly reverse the following year, given the dismantling of the European quota system.

Material impact to FV, as in our view sugar profits should command a 10x/PE (on cal
2017 estimates), given mid-term risks. While accepting the strong visibility of white space
supported by Primark's early stage expansion in Europe (and potentially the US, even if here we still are in the very early stages), we are also cognizant of the model's shortcomings in a multi-channel world. With most KPIs still on a deteriorating trend (margin, ROCE and potentially new space factor), we downgrade our Primark fair value from 26x to 23x, and ABF's TP to 2300p.

Valuation/Risks
Valuation: 2300p = SOTP placing Primark's CY 2017E earnings on 23x, sugar on 10x and
the balance on c.18x. Risks: further sugar price spikes, accelerating US expansion, US$/
cotton price falls.

BE

@Soundbuy, I was curious about that phrase as well.

BE

So I scanned back to the note, which is on a trip to Guildford.

11:53 am
BE

A recent shopping trip to Primark in Guildford highlighted
major changes in the trading stance. These included both very extensive price resets (10%
to 50%) and clearance activity (with mark downs of between 30% and 70%, on both A/W
and S/S merchandise). This is a major deviation from the norm for Primark, a format that
typically trades very much at full price for most of the season. It also comes at a time when
most other major players appear to be holding the line on trading discipline. We had the
opportunity to check two other central London stores, and one in central Frankfurt. The
changes were as stark here as in Surrey.
Roll-backs of 5%? We found that the S/S Primark basket that we monitor saw an average
decline in prices of c.3.2%, before price resets. This compares with -5% both at H&M and
Zara UK. The new price cuts added c.5% of incremental deflation, taking the YoY Primark
price fall to 8.5%. We also cross-referenced the strength of Primark's prices relative to two
rapidly growing UK online specialists (Bohoo [BOO LN, Buy, 50p] and Missguided). We
found an advantage of c.40% and 60% respectively for Primark in womenswear. Given this,
we are unsure why the business felt a mid-season, clearly unplanned price reset was needed.
However, at this juncture it is difficult to discern whether this action is in response to specific
competitive developments or a temporary reaction to an adverse trading context

BE

BE

So, there you go.

11:54 am
undefined
BE

I'm not sure what's going on on the right today. On a surface reading it's a bit like straying into the inter-office Slack chat for the Taxpayers' Alliance.

BE

But providing you're all happy, I'm happy.

11:56 am
BE

In amongst it I think I saw a request for IQE

IQE PLC (IQE:LSE): Last: 27.65, down 0.6001 (-2.12%), High: 30.50, Low: 27.50, Volume: 6.78m
BE

A company that -- how do I put this politely -- divides opinion.

11:57 am
BE

..... And has in the past attracted some quite lively investors.

BE

(@roddy1234: I'm fine, ta. The one thing worse than being ignored is to not be ignored, as Oscar Wilde definitely didn't say.)

BE

Update looks .... okay, I guess. Here's Singer.

11:59 am
BE

IQE’s interim results show continued progress with growth in all business segments. Group revenue grew 18% y-o-y to £63.0m with adjusted operating profit up 61% to £10.8m. The Wireless segment grew 7% but strong growth elsewhere saw dependence on this market continue to reduce (now c.69% of revenue). Photonics continues to be the growth engine, with revenue up 45% in the period. While this rate of growth in Photonics may not be sustainable in the long term it leaves the group very well placed to meet our full year expectations. Good cash generation saw continued reduction in group leverage (net debt plus deferred consideration) although increased capex will result in an increase to our net debt expectations for the full year. The shares have performed well since the trading update in July but still trade on an FY’16 PER of less than 10x. We believe this remains attractive and retain our Buy recommendation.

BE

And Canaccord.

BE

A strong first half to June 2016 saw revenues up 18% to £63m, adjusted operating margins up from 13% to 18%, adjusted diluted EPS up 62% and representing 54% of our full year forecast, balance sheet leverage reduced by 28% to £35.3m and £12.4m of cash generated from operations versus just £4.5m in the first half last year. The two key drivers of this strong performance were Photonics growth of 45% taking non-wireless sales up to 31% of the total from 24% in H1 2015, and license income of £3.5m from joint ventures, which all drops through to the bottom line. Wireless also performed well with a return to 7% growth after the sharp declines caused by de-stocking in H2 last year. Both Infrared and CMOS++ also produced small increases in sales. The net result is that IQE delivered impressive growth, improved margins, strong cash generation and reduced dependence on a wireless business that has proven to be a little unpredictable in the past. This all adds up to improved quality of earnings and leads us to upgrade our price target from 30p to 40p (15x 2016E P/E).

12:00 pm
BE

While these results showed operational progress in all areas of the business, they also benefited from a £3.5m license sale to JVs just as IQE had benefited from £8m of license sales in H2 last year. This is important to understanding the underlying performance of the business which had no license sales in the comparative period. Without this license sales growth would have been 12% instead of 18%, but the more important benefit was to margins. We note that without the license sale margins would have fallen to 12% from 13%, rather than rising to 18%. This should not detract from these strong results but sales to JVs do not enhance our quality of earnings argument as they are difficult to predict and may not be sustainable.

BE

Profits from Wireless were similar to H1 last year, but at £5.1m were substantially improved from £2.1m in H2 last year. If this performance is sustained in H2 we would need to upgrade our full year forecast, but the vagaries of chip supply mean that for now we leave our numbers unchanged. The real upside surprise in these numbers came from Phononics. The trading update in July suggested 'double digit' growth and IQE has delivered 45%. Given the operational gearing in this business, we were a little disappointed with margins up just 330bps but we anticipate stronger H2 margins, consistent with last year. We are particularly encouraged that the strong performance of both these businesses is backed up by a number of new initiatives and market developments that suggest the longer-term outlook for compound semiconductors has materially improved. In Wireless, these include the development of 3D imaging and use of optical sensors in handsets, the use of GaN on Si in base stations, the earlier than expected development of 5G and the potential to participate in smartphone filter technology when today IQE only has sales in the relatively low growth power amplifier segment of RF content. In Photonics, VCSEL epiwafers are expected to allow IQE to 'play' in the 'new era of laser technology' while increased use of fibre in datacentres and fibre to the premise is also expected to play to IQE's strengths in this area. Our 40p price target represents a FY16E P/E of 15x.

BE

But now that we don't have Arm, I guess IQE is the poster boy of listed British tech .....
